Notes:

You may need to rescale this object by a factor of 10 in Makerware since it is sized in cm not mm. You may also need to move the knot onto the platform, I think it is just above it. The knot is about 7cm x 7cm x7cm in size. This knot was first printed on a Project 260 3D Systems printer. Later, I printed it on the FormLabs 1+ printer in clear resin (02).

The 6_2 knot was exported from SeifertView, then opened it in Cinema4D. The surface of the knot needed fixing due to overlapping polygons. This was fixed by deleting overlapping polygons, then filling in the gaps using the Stitch and Sew tool in Edge Mode.

This bracket moves the Wanhao Duplicator i3 drag chain to the rear 20mm and down 1mm. This solves a number of issues: 1) Front clearance so wires don't rub against the the filament 2) the drag chain rubbing/catching the X-axis limit switch 3) holds in wires as you reach the top of the Z-axis 4) Cosmetically it cleans up the look.

I've tested Z-height clearance and I still can get to the full 180mm with it installed.

It's a little tricky to install but not super hard. Its easiest if you have a ball-end hex wrench. First attached the drag chain with the original 3mm flat top screws to the bracket and add lock nuts to them. Then use 3mm x 5mm cap screws to attach the bracket to the printer.

comments.text: I don't know if this works on the older versions, But on my monoprice V2.1 you can just flip the drag link mount and put the screws in through the opposite side. No printing anything required.
comments.author: spectrhz

comments.text: I have a BUNCH of extra wires because of fan replacements and using bullet connectors to connect my heating element after replacing it WOW  did this fix that mess for me. It looks better than stock now! For people asking about how to rotate the stepper motor or for those who don't want to do that but need some extra slack in the line to use this mod. Disconnect the cable chains that are attached to the Z Axis on the right side then you might be able to pull the cable a bit either at the spot where the upper cable chain connects or the lower one. If neither of those allow you to pull in some slack at the bottom where the black wire "wrap" connects to the cable chain there is a zip tiw a few inches down holding all of it together. Snip that zip tie and try pulling slack again.

This WS2812 holder allows to easily glue wires to single WS2812 chips (see also the photo). You can buy commercial wire glue or just make your own (like me) using graphite and glue. If you are adventurous you can also use a soldering iron but obviously you should not touch the holder. See here for some more tips.

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

If you want it to be two colors, use one until around 70% (72% for me exactly). Then watch very closely and when it starts on the third tier, quickly pause the print and switch filament. It may help to start with a darker color on the bottom and a lighter color on top so if you switch them too late it won't show as much. Also, it is better to switch later rather than earlier because an extra layer can hide underneath the rest of the colors while a layer on top of the lower tier sticks out (if switched too early).

Takes about 20 minutes.

comments.text: I shrunk it significantly. The end result was about 24mm by 30mm.  At this time, with 25% infill and a .2mm layer heighr, i can knock the item out in 7 minutes - it takes longer to warm than it does to print.  i had been printing the items in ABS with a 104C bed temperature and a 255C head temp. For TPU I wanted a bed temp of 70C and a head temp around 230C.  I also wanted the fan on all the time.

comments.text: Did you manually add a brim around it?  That might help with adhesion to the bed on such a small object.  I've had a good luck with that when I print things that either start small or have a point against the bed.  Good luck with this project!  Post a picture or two so that we can see how it turned out.  Hope it goes well!

title: Conway's Game of Life Object Generator

description.text: This is a set of scripts that uses Golly (see http://golly.sourceforge.net/), a cross-platform cellular automata engine, to create objects that represent the evolution of a pattern over several generations on the Z axis using the rules of Conway's Game of Life. The scripts generate OpenSCAD (see http://www.openscad.org/) programs, which you can use to create STL files for printing. The demo object represents eight generations of evolution of a glider.

Install Golly, and then install "golly script/openscad.py" in your Golly script directory and launch it directly from Golly. It will evolve the currently loaded pattern for the specified number of generations and create and OpenSCAD file representing the object. There is also a script that will take the names of a series of .rle files as input, so you can manually save the various generations of a pattern from Golly and then run the "solid_conway.py" script on the lot. The latest code is available on GitHub at https://github.com/phooky/SolidConway.

remixed_from.title: Holder for wireless Samsung S6 Charger

title: Samsung Fast Wireless Charger (Galaxy S7/S7 edge) Dock

description.text:
Was wanting to find a dock for my Samsung Fast Wireless charger but all of the ones here were for the original Samsung wireless charger which is about the same diameter but much thinner. The other big difference is that for heat dissipation the new charger has a very small fan in the back and therefore requires ventilation. hbaulig's design seemed to be pretty open for ventilation so I extruded it's depth a bit. I had to make some tweaks to change the holder to be convex rather than concave like the original puck and added more ventilation holes in the back. It's a rather snug fit for the puck but it holds well and the cable management is top 'notch'. Note that the puck is intended to be installed Upside Down so that the Samsung microUSB cable can be plugged in through the tunnel inside the dock.

Update 1: I was having ventilation problems with the first version (puck would start flashing and stop charging occasionally), so I uploaded an update that has larger vent holes and is slightly larger to more easily fit the puck.

Update 2: Based on feedback, I updated the dock with a deeper phone tray to accommodate cases and leveled the feet so that they properly contact the floor and removes unnecessary support material on the feet issues some folks have. Download Samsung Wireless Fast Charger Dock v3.stl for the update. Note that the file is quite a bit bigger than the previous versions due to smoothing I did with MeshMixer. I'll have to see if I can find an app to simplify the mesh to reduce size.

title: Nefertiti Hack (Neues Museum Germany) Three Piece Model

description.text:
Nefertiti

This is a cut version of the Nefertiti model from the Neues Museum in Germany.

It is presented in three pieces consisting of the shoulders, face, and crown. The face will print upside down to minimize support.

This strategy will also aid in failed prints so you only need to finish 1/3 of the sculpture at a time to achieve a successful print.

I believe the crown piece is the largest, so the largest size it can be scaled will give dimensions on the largest size you can print the other two pieces.

The largest side for the crown is approximately 10.11 inches or 256mm - this will fit on a stock Rostock Max and perhaps some other brands of 3D printers.

The seam along the neck is somewhat hidden under the chin and I attempted to match the seam on the crown with the border element along the forehead.

Enjoy!

Further Reading:

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/02/arts/design/other-nefertiti-3d-printer.html?_r=2

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/11/arts/design/nefertiti-3-d-scanning-project-in-germany-raises-doubts.html

http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/03/one-of-the-greatest-art-heists-of-our-time-was-actually-a-data-hack/

https://cosmowenman.wordpress.com/2016/03/08/the-nefertiti-3d-scan-heist-is-a-hoax/

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nefertiti

The crown has a slight bit of support as well depending on your overhang angle.

The original Nefertiti Hack model was cut into pieces with Netfabb.

The scale is unchanged and the polygon count is unaltered.

title: DIY Linear Translational Stage - Micrometer resolution

description.text:
This Linear Translational Stage is developed to provide the same functionality a standard lab linear translational stage, but at a fraction of the cost.  
The sliding block is moved with micrometer resolution using a micrometer screw at a disance up to 15mm. Suitable for use with optical equipment and for positioning various things with high precision.  
There are two parts to the design. Small short-test pieces are to be printed in a few minutes to check dimensions and accuracy of the printer. If the blocks do not slide, the edge of the Rail needs to be chamfered a bit more.  
After completing this test step, print the full design as indicated on the image. Note that the Rail must be printed top-down (counterintuitive) to ensure the smoothnes of the edce on which the sliding occurs. Do not worry about the roughness of the connecting sections above the gap, there is space to accomodate for it.
Printed using ABS 0.1mm layers, parts positioned and rotated as shown in images! This is a must!

title: Torque meter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple torque meter to measure the hold torque of small motor like stepper motor. By means a known weight connected to the torque meter by means of a string, we can measure the torque using a simple formula:
Torque[cNm]= weight[N] x arm[mm] x 0.1

the torque meter give the dimension of the arm in order to equilibrate the torque of the motor. The measure of the arm in [mm] can be read directly on the torque meter.

author: patdelin

description.text: Links sword

This is a can holder shifter knob made for .33 soda cans. You can mount it on your shifter rod.

Measure your shifter rod and pick the version which fits yours, 12mm or 14 mm. You can customize the diameter in the .scad file, in the .zip file. In the .scad file you can also customize the dimensions of the can holder to make it fit your coffee cup or beer special soda can.

Make sure the soda can fit's perfectly(not too tight, not too lose), you don't want it to wobble around.

Because it's pretty stupid to have a can holder as a shifter knob you might spill soda everywhere, but that's ok because it's pretty awesome too.

It's pretty bad-ass to casually pick up your mountain dew can after effortlessly shifting to sixth gear while cruising down the highway.

• Print speed: slow, to make it strong,

  • Infill: High, 40%++, to make it strong.

  • Support: not needed

  • Material: ABS or something the can handle can heat, PLA is probably ok in some cases.

title: Simple Migbot Prusa i3 spool holder

description.text: This is a simplistic spool holder I designed for my Migbot Prusa, which uses RepRapDiscount smart controller. It's mounted by sandwiching between the controller board and printer's acrylic frame.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Migbot Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Doesn't matter much

Infill:

Anything above 20...30%

Notes:

I probably would recommend not infilling it up 100% not just because of the amount of plastic required, but to keep it flexible up to certain extent. While it's a nice dust cover and mounting standoff for the controller, it itself is quite thin, sits quite high on the printer frame, and has a reasonable amount of weight in form of a filament spool sitting on top of it.
Therefore, I definitely woudn't want to stress it by knocking it into things and (not very likely, but) possibly damaging printer acrylic frame.
Just a bit of a warning, and common sense :)

title: Dragon's Egg Lightshade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Inspired by a dragon's egg.. or what they could look like if you imagined one ;-) Design intended for dualstrusion, but monostruders, do not despair:
You can print "Net" or "Surface" as standalones. Circa 11 cm high, scale as needed. So there are two different models:
One where the pattern is embedded near the surface. (Left)
And one where the pattern is completely embedded in the shell. (Right)

Suitable for dual extrusion printers.
There are four files of which you only need two in one print:
Always use the "Net" stl and combine with either a one "Surface" OR "Embedded" stl
Please look at the split render to see the full difference.
There is a thin and a thicker version of the Surface shell, choose which one your printer can handle.
The 2mm is also a nice standalone print.

This first version of the library comes with five smily styles: :), :D, :(, ;), and :|

The zip contains all the other files listed.

• Include smily.scad to gain access to these functions.
    • / Draws some smily examples
    /
    smily_examples(); // this will display some examples / Creates a smily face
  • type - string. Type of smily. :) = normal, :D = big smile, :( = frown, ;) = wink, :| = expressionless
  • radius - float. The radius of the smily face
  • height - float. The height of the smily face, specify 0 for 2D smily
  • line_thickness - float. The thickness of the lines in the drawing
  • inverse - bool. Not a true inverse. Draws outlines instead of filling in.
    */
    smily(type = ":)", radius = 20, height = 5, line_thickness = 2, inverse = false)
    • SMILE!

This miniature terrain piece was designed for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Very Customizable Ruler - Secret Geneva Machanism Pencil Box - Trapped Sphere Pencil Topper

description.text:
This is a tour de force #backtoschool set!
Make a very fancy Ruler to the exact specifications you want.
The pencil case opens to reveal the heart warming Geneva Mechanism!
And who does not want a trapped sphere pencil topper. I do so I made one.
video here of box http://youtu.be/cQUxT1wyrOY also to help educate your friends and family, best I have found under 2 minute slightly amusing, simple & straight forward explanation of home 3D printing, (made by and for schools):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YpHv19jdloI

--the ruler is a .scad file, you can make pretty much any ruler you want, key chains, normal rulers, sample print swatches. i took this file far beyond the basic one Stu121 started me off with.
-- the pencil case was made in tinkercad, then I added a secret to the inside of the lid using Geneva mechanism from jessed, I improved pins and spacing of the original.
-- pencil topper is a simple add on to the file from liefting Printed these in PLA 0.2mm layer height, 20%fill, wall=2Xnozzle (in this case 0.7mm wall since I use the MakerGear M2 with 0.35mm nozzle)

description.text: Three interlocking trefoil knots designed by Hayley Archer-McClelland and edited by Dave Pfaff and myself as part of my Math 341 Introduction to Topology course in Fall 2014. Each trefoil knot is linked with the two others.

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Form 1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You may need to rescale this object by a factor of 10 in Makerware since it is sized in cm not mm. You may also need to move the knot onto the platform, I think it is just above it. The model is about 9cm x 10cm x 5cm in size.

These knots were first printed on a Project 260 3D Systems printer. Later they were printed on a FormLabs 1+ printer using clear resin (02).

Designed entirely in Cinema4D. The parametric equations of a trefoil knot are x(t)= (2+cos(3t))cos(2t), y=(2+cos(3t))sin(2t), z=-sin(3t) from t=-pi to t=pi.

We first made the curve with the Formula function from t=-3.14 to t=3.14. We added a SweepNurb (with no caps) consisting of a circle with radius 0.2cm around the curve. The choice of t meant there was a small gap between the ends of the tube. We sealed this using the Stitch and Sew tool in Edge mode.

The rosary's pearls are spheres (7.5mm and 10mm) from my "Ball Head Links System" collection. title: Customizable Car Vent Sunglass Holder v1.0

description.text:
This is Version 1.0. See the latest version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2156682

This is my first, original, customizable OpenSCAD design. This is a car vent sunglass holder with a ball and socket connector. It is very small and unobtrusive on your dash, but keeps the sunglasses handy.

The cool thing about this Thingy, is the printing of the ball in the socket all at once. There is just a little resistance to the ball turning when you first take it off the print bed. But, a little twist breaks it free and it turns nicely in the socket.

print_settings.Notes:: You can modify the sketchup file to change the height if needed.

title: Anti warp pad, hollow for faster tape down

description.text:
This is an improved version of the Anti Warp Pad. The best way to use those is to tape them down, but that usually means waiting for the first layer to finish. The improved pads only print the outline which, depending slicer settings, gets printed first. Thus the taping down can be done in seconds instead of waiting several minutes.

The pads helps keep the corners from warping. Since the settings in Cura and others usually generate a bit more brim than necessary I designed this. Put as many as needed around your print, they easily twist off afterwards. Cura complains about overlapping parts but still generates perfectly fine gcode.

Sorry about the lousy photos, my mirror makes for great prints but bad lighting.

print_settings.Notes:: This knot was first printed on a Project 260 3D Systems printer. Later it was printed on a FormLabs 1+ printer.

description.text: A (5,3) ribbon-like torus knot designed by Emily Jaekle and edited by Dave Pfaff and myself from my Math 341 Introduction to Topology class in Fall 2014.

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Form 1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

You may need to rescale this object by a factor of 10 in Makerware since it is sized in cm not mm. You may also need to move the knot onto the platform, I think it is just above it. The knot is about 9cm x 10cm x 4cm in size.

This knot was first printed on a Project 260 3D Systems printer. Later it was printed on a FormLabs 1+ printer.

This (5,3) ribbon torus knot was designed entirely in Cinema4D. The curve was created using the Formula tool with parametrization x=(2+cos(5t))cos(3t), y=(2+cos(5t))sin(3t), z=-sin(5t) from t=-pi to t=pi. The trianglulated surface was created by first adding in a small rectangle, then using the SweepNurbs (without caps). The rectangle was also rotated 1800 degrees in the process. The small gap was fixed using the Bridge tool in Edge mode.

remixed_from.author: PharaohABQ
remixed_from.title: Eric's Improved Z Axis Coupler Rev3

title: Eric's Improved Z Axis Coupler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 1/12/2012
Added .PK2 and .STL for 4mm stepper shafts *EDIT Rev2, I made some adjustments to the columns and verified that the .PK2 file works in Creo again. I printed a new one and it looks better than the first one I uploaded. Let me know what you think. Use EricCoupler2 for the newer version.. I also found Thing# 12190, which is really similar, he made his first so I've listed this as a derivative though I created mine separately before I saw his. This coupler came from my seeing and experiencing issues with other couplers. I wanted a Z coupler that was round and would not snag any loose wires. I wanted one that I would not have to worry about slippage, and that would be beefy. After a little experimentation, I decided the captive nut idea was the best. This is my first posted Thing, so Comments are certainly welcome. I design objects with PTC Creo. It's awesome. Elements is Free.

Print, Cut out the support columns, insert a 5/16 or 8MM nut in the big slot. Insert a 3mm nut in the little slot Then a short 3mm screw in the little hole to hold the 5mm motor shaft.  Put a 5/16 or 8mm nut on your Z axis threaded rod, then screw the rod into the captive nut through the bottom hole till it stops, then tighten the nut below night too tight against the bottom.  This provides a little wiggle, but should be centric to the motor shaft. See picture.  
Dimensions 20mmdia.x30mmtall

comments.text: Apparently the .PK2 file from Creo didn't save the object correctly.  I have to go back to an earlier save and put it back up.  Sorry for any inconvienence. :'( The .STL file still works well.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

comments.text: You are definitely on to something here.  I had some difficulties though.  Evidently I did not do a good enough job removing the supporting posts you put in the design to help with the bridging.  The bolt would not go in easily and I ended up cracking the plastic.  I also could not get the 3mm nut into the slot at the top.  Still, I think this is the best concept for a coupler I have seen.  I wonder if the nut could be fully encased and avoid the bridge issue by pausing the print, to allow the nut to be inserted, then restarting?  Not sure how Skeinforge could do that though.
comments.author: coffeetron

comments.text: I have been looking at ways to fix that bridging issue.  maybe smaller points in the columns.  I dunno.   I'll work on it.   The 3mm nut I knew would be tight.  I'll open the gaps a little more to make it easier, same for the hole for the set screw, it's a little tight, 4mm should work I think.

remixed_from.author: TTB_Studios
remixed_from.title: MakeBlock Drawbot (XY Plotter) X-Axis Carriage & Pen Lift Mechanism (Linear Actuator)

description.text:
3DP MakeBlock XYP (plotter/drawbot) full upgrade.
http://www.makeblock.cc/xy-plotter-robot-kit/

I wasn't happy with the carriage design of the MakeBlock XY Plotter (drawbot) so I took it upon myself to redesign the X & Y axis carriages but I didn't stop there! I basically made my own version of an XY Plotter utilizing 3D printed parts versus extruded aluminum blocks bolted together.
Now there are just 24 (or 28 is using 3d printed pulley holders) 3D printed parts coupled with the Makeblock parts: 8mm bearings/holders (6 total), 4x 8mm linear rods, 4x 18t MXL pulleys (or possibly GT2?), 10x shaft bearings, 3x 3mm OD x 40mm length rod (makeblock provides 56mm length), 1x 3mm OD x 510mm length rod, 3 drive belts provided by Makeblock, some 3/8" (9.5mm) wooden dowels/rod and a handful of 3mm nuts and bolts.

This upgrade will bring the working area from 310mm × 390mm up to 340mm x 400mm which I was very happy with. (roughly 16" x 13.5") Plus with a vertical pen lift mechanism, the drawing precision has increased tremendously.

I would like to find silent/near silent micro-servo's as the servo supplied is far from quiet.

More info here soon

This is a small pins jig I designed a few hours ago.

To secure the hinges on my RC planes, I use some pins cut and place vertically through the balsa and the hinge. To cut the pins, I use a wire cutter. To ensure that all my pins cuts have the right length, I designed this little jig.
To use it, place the pin in the right hole, put the cutter on the jig and cut. This will ensure all pieces have (almost) the same length.
I'm not sure it will be of any help for someone else, but... :-)
The Openscad source file is also available to allow customization.

description.text: This is a (3,2) ribbon torus knot designed by Cathy Wang and edited by Dave Pfaff and myself for my Math 341 Introduction to Topology class in Fall 2014.

Notes:

You may need to rescale this object by a factor of 10 in Makerware since it is sized in cm not mm. You may also need to move the knot onto the platform, I think it is just above it. The knot is about 10cm x 11cm x 5cm in size. This knot was first printed on a Projet-260 3D Systems printer.

The entire model was designed in Cinema4D. The knot was created using the Formula tool with parametrization x=(2+cos(2t))cos(3t), y=(2+cos(2t))sin(3t), z=-sin(2t) from t=-pi to t=pi. The trianglulated surface was created by first adding in a small rectangle, then using the SweepNurbs (without caps). The width and height of the rectangle was adjusted so the band is not a constant size through the knot. The overlapping edges and small gaps were also fixed. Finally, the knot was colored with a beautiful rainbow-gradient. (The color doesn't show in the .stl file.)

These files are to cut out a set of wood gears at 18" diameter, 12" diameter, and 8" diameter. The gears were used as part of a high school engineering class. More details can be found at Teaching Engineering

The gears needed some hand sanding before meshing perfectly together. Could be used for a wide variety of projects.

There are two types of files.
.DFX files which can be opened by many different drawing, CAD, and CAD-CAM software

*You must have a good understanding of the Shopbot safety settings and features before using the .CRV files. If you are unsure how to set material depths and tools feeds and speed please ask or do further research.

I took the original model, cut it in half in netfabb, loaded the resulting stl in openjscad, renamed the resulting function to tardis, translated the model to the middle, and did a difference of that and a cylinder of 15mm diameter and 2mm height.

Like:

function main( )
{
var object = tardis( ).rotateX( -90 );
var bounds = object.getBounds( );
var x = bounds[ 1 ].x + ( bounds[ 0 ].x - bounds[ 1 ].x ) / 2;
var y = bounds[ 1 ].y + ( bounds[ 0 ].y - bounds[ 1 ].y ) / 2;
var z = min( bounds[ 0 ].z, bounds[ 1 ].z );
return difference( object.translate( [ - x, - y, - z ] ), cylinder( { d: 15.8, h: 2 } ) );
}

I could probably drop the netfabb side, but was being lazy. The resultant model needed to be repaired though.

description.text: This is a Seifert surface of a figure 8 knot designed by Mithra Muthukrishnan and edited by Dave Pfaff and myself for my Math 341 Introduction to Topology class in Fall 2014. The colored model shows the knot in pink/red, one side of the Seifert surface in white and the other side in yellow

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You may need to rescale this object by a factor of 10 in Makerware since it is sized in cm not mm. You may also need to move the knot onto the platform, I think it is just above it. The knot is about 8cm x 8cm x 10cm in size. This knot was first printed on a Project 260 3D Systems printer.

This was a complex design. The figure-8 knot and its Seifert surface was first created in SeifertView. After exporting the file, we opened it in Cinema4D. There the surface was extruded in both directions creating the two sides of the Seifert surface. Finally, three copies of the surface were made. In one, all the surfaces were deleted leaving the knot. In another the knot and one side of the extrusion was deleted. In the final copy, the knot and the other side of the extrusion was deleted. This left three pieces which could each be given their own color before printing. For the .stl file here, the model is just in one piece.

comments.text: The creator of SeifertView gave Washington & Lee University (my institution) a version of the program which enables you to export what you've created to a file. I would contact him directly and see if he can do something similar for you.

I made a Sketchup model of the MakerBot so I could test out some paint schemes.
cupcake.skp consists of all of the 5mm laser cut parts from Batch 3-4, with a slight tweak to remove the tape dispenser.

Download and color just like you are on kindergarten, only in 3D!

description.text: Official Write-Up at http://www.protoparadigm.com/2011/12/abs-glue-weld-cast-texture-and-more/ Here's something that should make plastic life a lot easier. Fuse parts, smooth, shine and texture prints, even cast ABS at room temperature.

The blog post above does a much better job of explaining and demonstrating than is possible in these descriptions. Check it out! !! Use in a well ventilated area and avoid skin contact !!

  • Mix 1/3 filament clippings to 2/3 Acetone in a cleaned out nail enamel/polish container.

  • Swirl about and wait to set.
    • Fuse/Weld:
    Brush on surfaces to be joined and press together, hold or support long enough to set. Such as Plastic T-Slot http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10261 Shine, Smooth, Texture:
    Experiment with different concentrations of filament to Acetone and brushes to paint a layer over your prints, smoothing them or lay a textured surface against surface transferring desired texture. Cold Casting:
    Print PLA molds. Apply multiple applications of ABS Glue as the Acetone evaporates. A light concentration to straight Acetone at the top can help smooth the top surface. The ProtoParadigm Logo in the images is an example of this process. Dried glue can be peeled or scraped off where applied accidentally. These are only a few of the uses we've explored. Make some, try it out and see what you come up with.

comments.text: This works great. I find it takes several hours (at least overnight) to fully cure, but once it does it's definitely stronger than the printed layers from my makerbot!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hi , Using a mix of this nature works awesome to stick the prints down but I find wiping with acetone degrades the sufrace layer of the Kapton Tape (under a microscope)  it tends to tear easier after having acetone wiped on the tape,

comments.text: Just in case people don't know, you can buy clear or black ABS cement in the plumbing department of most hardware stores.  1 can will last quite a while.  You can also make thick layers for filling gaps (it turns into sturdy ABS).  I use it with my Makerbot all the time.

comments.text: Sure can, I'd be hesitant to use it in all the situations I use this. I like knowing the grade of ABS I'm using matches what i'm printing with (they can all be very different) and appreciate having control over the color and consistency.

comments.text: Just standard hardware store Acetone. Those numbers were referring to the ratio; for the ratio of 2:1 Acetone to filament I just pour in the acetone first to about half way and then put in filament until another quarter of the container is full. That way there is still a quarter left to experiment with to get the consistency I want. It's not super critical, as you'll probably play around getting it where you want it. If you're only fusing pieces together it doesn't take much filament in there to be effective.

title: Drag Factor Scale for Concept 2 Model B Rowing Machine

description.text:
This is a scale to accompany my adjustment lever (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:753360) It's designed to fit on a home built 480mm diameter 'speed disc' which brings the drag factor down in line with the newer models. The drag factor of my Model B ergo can now easily be adjusted from 95 to 220 without leaving the seat.
(Leave a comment if you have an ergo and this is gibberish to you and I'll happily elucidate.)

The numbering is just laser printed on paper, attached using double-sided sticky-tape and lacquered. Rename the 'ErgoStrip.txt' file to 'ErgoStrip.docx', (docx uploads not allowed) print it off and cut to size. Determine the scale position on the speed disc and attach with glue or strong foam tape.

author: AndyGadget

description.text:
We have an active and growing makerspace here in Chattanooga. To keep everyone safe, I thought a safety plug for our 50A outlet was a really good idea, especially for smaller fingers. This plug configuration is the same as Miller's 220v plug for many of their welders and plasma cutters. 50 amp, 250 volt, NEMA 6-50R, 2-pole, 3-wire outlet
Lowes: http://goo.gl/LlXakb
Home Depot: http://goo.gl/fdveIp
This thing was made in OnShape. It is made to hold certain length wires and LEDs
